Enforcement Action

Gathering force: U.S. securities law gives regulators, notably the SEC, leeway to police firms that sell third-party information such as geolocation records or credit-card transactions to investors.

The SEC said Tuesday it settled securities fraud charges with App Annie Inc., which analyzes data about consumers' mobile app usage, for misleading developers about its privacy controls.

"We see this as not just a precedent in terms of what actions might come against data vendors, but it really, finally gives us some insights into how the SEC thinks about the risks associated with these data products," said Kelly Koscuiszka, a partner at New York law firm Schulte Roth & Zabel.

Read the full story.

More Cyber and Privacy News

Not compliant: New Zealand's privacy commissioner issued a notice of noncompliance to the Reserve Bank of New Zealand for failure to properly store and secure certain personal data, related to a cyberattack late last year on one of its tech vendors. The bank was among several customers of Accellion Inc. affected by the hack of the tech firm's File Transfer Appliance software, a 20-year-old tool to share large documents.

Consulting firm KPMG found shortcomings in the bank's data-handling practices during an internal review the bank requested after learning of the software breach. The privacy commissioner said its findings jibe with KPMG's and the bank is working to fix flaws in its data-protection program. (Reseller News)

A grand jury has indicted a high-profile cybersecurity lawyer in connection with special counsel John Durham's investigation into the origins of the FBI's Russia probe, on charges that he lied to investigators during the 2016 presidential campaign. Attorney Michael Sussmann of Perkins Coie, a law firm tied to the Democratic Party, is charged with making a false statement during a meeting with officials of the FBI shortly before the 2016 election.
